content.question: A student wants to compare the thermal conductivities of several metal rods with different lengths <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and cross-sectional areas <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student connects each rod to two reservoirs, one containing a hot liquid at temperature <math alttext="100 degrees Celsius " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the other containing an ice bath at <math alttext="0 degrees Celsius " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in the figure. Each rod is kept in contact with the reservoirs for the same fixed time interval <math alttext="delta lowercase t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the amount of energy transferred through a rod in the time <math alttext="delta lowercase t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following lists all the additional quantities that must be measured to be able to compare the thermal conductivities?

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
